characters: VALENTINE'S DAY, BUT IT WAS REALLY WARM
"DAD'S IN BED IN COOK COUNTY HOSPITAL."
OKAY... WHY NOT GIVE ME A CALL ON JULY 10, 2004, AT ABOUT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy takes a deep breath, then pulls away from the house. Dog next to her in the passenger seat. She drives down the road, gaining speed. She suddenly stops, remembering something.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Shit. Sorry. She puts the car in reverse. Backs up until she is next to the mailbox. She reaches out the window, opens the box and puts an envelope inside. She strains to reach the flag. The dog watches. She finally succeeds in pulling the flag to the upright position.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Okay. She puts the car in gear. It disappears down the road. ON the raised red flag.

dialogues.speaker: CREDITS OVER.
dialogues.text: As Lucy drives south, the Lake on her left. She passes a sign: CHICAGO 60 MILES. Traffic gets denser as she approaches the city. Soon the skyline is right on top of her and she's in it, at the height of the morning rush -- crowds, traffic, noise, energy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pulls up outside an APARTMENT BUILDING on a densely- packed North Side street. It's a very new building, cold and sterile. The contrast with the tranquillity of the Lake House is striking. She parks the car, gets out. Takes a moment to absorb the change in her surroundings. Then she starts to unload her things. END CREDITS.

dialogues.speaker: A MAILBOX
dialogues.text: A very ordinary one -- metal, mounted on a post, hinged red flag on the side. The flag is down. The SOUND of waves lapping the shore. PULL BACK. Beyond the mailbox is LAKE MICHIGAN, endless and blue-gray on this overcast winter morning. And on the Lake, hugging the shore, is a LAKE HOUSE. This house, unlike its mailbox, is striking. It’s at the end of a narrow jetty or walkway that shoots out into the Lake. It is perched on stilts right above the water, where it seems to float. Its design is modern, and in another setting it might be slightly austere, but here the fit with its surroundings is so perfect that the overall effect is one of serenity. It is dawn. A smudge of sun can be seen rising in the space between the sun and the surface of the Lake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LUCY FORSTER, 30, lovely, watches the sunrise through a huge window that faces the water. After a while and with evident difficulty, she tears herself away. She pulls on a coat and goes to the front door. The house is empty; Lucy is moving out. She opens the door and takes a final look back. Her eyes fall on someone.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: You coming or not? A SMALL DOG is hesitating in the middle of the room.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Last chance...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy walks across the jetty to the road, where her car is waiting, packed full of bones. The dog trots after her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The corridors of a huge urban hospital, crowded with PATIENTS, FAMILIES, ORDERLIES. It’s chaotic and loud. Lucy comes in. She walks to the main desk, tries to flag down a busy ATTENDANT.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: Just a minute, okay? Lucy waits for a minute, then tries to catch the Attendant again as she blows past.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Excuse me, I need to -- The Attendant hands her a clipboard.

dialogues.speaker: ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: Just fill this out and wait over there for me, okay? Lucy hands it back.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: No, I’m Doctor Forster. I’ma new resident. They told me to report here.

dialogues.speaker: ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: Oh, I’m sorry, Doctor. You need to find Dr. Klyczynski. She should be around here. Older lady, kinda tough, like this tall...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANNA KLYCZYNSKI, 45, no-nonsense manner, walks fast down the corridor. Lucy next to her, trying to keep up. Klyczynski hands her a big stack of files.

dialogues.speaker: KLYCZYNSKI
dialogues.text: You’re covering 22 patients on rounds today, this floor and the next.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Twenty-two? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: KLYCZYNSKI
dialogues.text: Quiet morning. If you get into trouble you can beep me, but try to keep it to a minimum. The med students are supposed to help you out with scut work. If you can find one. Lucy is looking a little dazed. They pass a patient on a bed in the corridor. Klyczynski flags down a NURSE.

dialogues.speaker: KLYCZYNSKI
dialogues.text: What’s he doing here? I ordered an immediate MRI.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Transport said about four hours.

dialogues.speaker: KLYCZYNSKI
dialogues.text: Shit. All right. She turns to Lucy, takes the files back, points.

dialogues.speaker: KLYCZYNSKI
dialogues.text: Doctor Forster, push him down to MRI -- that’s a left, another left, a right, elevator to two, follow the signs. Then hustle back here for rounds...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy with a stack of charts, reeling around, trying to find her next patient. She’s lost in the busy corridors. Another young woman doctor, MADHVI PATEL, appears, glances at her chart.

dialogues.speaker: PATEL
dialogues.text: Wrong floor. Lucy makes a frustrated sound. Patel guides her to an elevator.

dialogues.speaker: PATEL
dialogues.text: Takes a while to get your bearings. I’m Madhvi. You’re the new resident, right?

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: (nods) Lucy. Forster. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PATEL
dialogues.text: Where did you do your internship?

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: A little community hospital. Up on the North Shore.

dialogues.speaker: PATEL
dialogues.text: Well, just think of this as a little community hospital, only with more gunshot wounds. She smiles, but Lucy doesn’t acknowledge the attempt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy comes off shift, very tired. Patel and another resident, TOM COSTELLO, are changing clothes to go home. They nod at Lucy. She smiles wearily.

dialogues.speaker: PATEL
dialogues.text: How was your first night?

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: I’m... not sure.

dialogues.speaker: COSTELLO
dialogues.text: Nor should you be. A state of dazed near-panic is normal for the first few months. Lucy smiles politely.

dialogues.speaker: PATEL
dialogues.text: Luckily there is a cure.

dialogues.speaker: COSTELLO
dialogues.text: The Cove.

dialogues.speaker: PATEL
dialogues.text: The Cove.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: What’s that?

dialogues.speaker: COSTELLO
dialogues.text: Bar around the corner. Open all night. Acceptable burgers. Cheap beer in unwashed glasses.

dialogues.speaker: PATEL
dialogues.text: It’s heavenly. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy realizes they’re inviting her to come with them. She hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Thanks. Better not. I’m dead.

dialogues.speaker: COSTELLO
dialogues.text: We all are.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: And I’ve still got a lot of unpacking to do... Patel and Costello nod. If they’re put out by her refusal, they don’t show it.

dialogues.speaker: COSTELLO
dialogues.text: Next time, then. INT. LUCY’S APARTMENT Lucy comes home. Her apartment is small, sterile. She hasn’t had time to unpack and boxes are strewn everywhere. As she enters, her DOG LEAPS UP on her, WHIMPERING. Lucy jumps, startled, then puts the dog down, goes into the kitchen and flicks the light on. Nothing happens.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: (mutters) Need light bulbs. She opens the (bare) fridge for the light. She pours dog food into a bowl, emptying the bag.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Need dog food. And human food...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her bedroom is as functional and depressing as the rest of the place. A loud SQUEAK as she walks into the room.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Fix loose floorboard. Lucy goes to the window. Outside -- a solid wall of other buildings, other windows. Very hard even to see the sky. She sighs. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Need view. She closes the blinds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON the mailbox, its flag still up. FIND a PICKUP TRUCK parked at the edge of the jetty. Its back is piled with furniture and moving boxes. A MAN is moving in to the house. Working alone, he heaves a large armchair off the truck and wrestles it along the jetty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man plugs in a lamp and switches it on. JULIAN, 30, tall, moody good looks. He surveys the place, pleased. He doesn’t have much. A stereo, some books, the armchair. But the spare furnishings fit with the austere beauty of the house. He looks out the window at the Lake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julian stocks up on groceries at a local shop. The young STOREOWNER and his WIFE behind the counter.

dialogues.speaker: STOREOWNER
dialogues.text: New in the area?

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: (smiles) More or less.

dialogues.speaker: STOREOWNER
dialogues.text: You’11 like it. Especially since it warms up a little. (indicating groceries) Let us get you some boxes for all that.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Okay, thanks. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His wife goes to take an empty box down from a high shelf. She is visibly pregnant. The Storeowner hurries over.

dialogues.speaker: STOREOWNER
dialogues.text: No, honey, let me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julian pulls up with his groceries in the back of the truck. He notices the mailbox with its raised flag. He stops and opens it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julian sits in his chair by the window, silhouetted against the moonlit Lake outside. A beer in his hand. He opens Lucy’s letter and reads.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: ‘Dear New Tenant. Hi and welcome to your new home and congratulations, etcetera. It’s a wonderful place, as you already know, and I’m sure you’ll love living here as much as I did. I’m the previous tenant by the way. Julian looks puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: ‘The post office is forwarding my mail but I wondered if you could send anything that might slip through. My new address is below. Thanks.’ (beat) “P.S.’ Julian flips the letter over.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: (reads) ‘Sorry about the paw prints by the front door. They were there when I moved in. Same with the box in the attic. I think it belongs to the owner.’ Julian stares at the letter.  10. He goes to the front door. The floor is clean. Nothing outside either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julian opens the door to an attic crawl space. He looks around. It’s empty. No boxes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julian shrugs, crumples the letter and throws it away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy walks up the stairs to the El, alone against the tide of people walking down -- they are coming home from work as she heads in for a night shift.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An ICU PATIENT in crisis. MONITORS BEEPING and flashing red. Lucy runs in, swiftly begins CPR, asks a nurse to prepare a syringe. Klyczynski appears and stands at the door, watching Lucy closely.

dialogues.speaker: KLYCZYNSKI
dialogues.text: You all right? Lucy keeps working. The patient’s crisis passes. The monitors quiet.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: I think we’re okay. Klyczynski nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy checks on a PATIENT -- teenage girl lying awake in a darkened room, watching TV.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Hey. You’re supposed to be asleep. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: I know, but --

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Sorry. Sometimes I’ve got to play bad cop. Lucy goes to switch off the TV. She pauses. It’s showing Cary Grant and Ingrid Bergman -- the long, long lingering kiss from Notorious. Lucy stares at it, transfixed. Then she sits down on the edge of the bed to watch. The girl looks at her, surprised. Klyczynski nods.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: My favourite part. INT. LUCY’S BEDROOM - DAWN After work. Lucy prepares for bed, a blindfold around her neck. She goes to the window to close the blinds against the morning light. She notices something outside. She gets up on tiptoe, straining. Then she pulls a chair over and stands on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By standing up high at the extreme edge of the window she can just make out, through a gap in the buildings, a tiny sliver of Lake Michigan. The sun is just coming up.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: She stands on the chair, staring at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THROUGH the Lake House window we can see the sun rising, huge, over the Lake. Julian is up, lacing up work boots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julian pulls up in his truck, arriving at a Lakeside building site -- dozens of future condos, now mostly foundations and a few half-finished frame skeletons. It’s a big operation.  12. An office set up in a large trailer on the site. Julian prepares for the day, consulting plans and schedules. MONA JAFFE (30s, brisk, stylish) on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: That’s right, each luxury residence has a private Lake view... They’re not available for viewing quite yet, but if you’d like me to add you to the list... yes, we absolutely expect to be ready on schedule. She throws a “right?” glance at Julian. He nods reassurance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dozens of Men working at various places around the site. FIND Julian walking quickly, conferring with MULHERN (40s, construction foreman, hard look).

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: I’d like to get the foundation for number 17 dug today. Mulhern looks at him with barely-disguised contempt.

dialogues.speaker: MULHERN
dialogues.text: I know you’re kinda new here.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: MULHERN
dialogues.text: I can’t get to that at least ‘til next week.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: (smoothly) Come on, Mulhern, that’s bullshit and you know it. Take Clemens and Rodriguez off roofing, Jorge can run the backhoe they’re not using on fourteen, and grab four or five of the other guys sitting on their asses on seven and ten -- Paulie, Frank, Carlos, Danny, and what’s his name, the tall kid, Rafael. Mulhern blinks.

dialogues.speaker: MULHERN
dialogues.text: Right.  13. Julian is the last man at work on the site at the end of the day. He hauls away some garbage and scrap. He’s about to throw out a couple of half-full cans of paint. He stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julian kneels on the jetty, applying a fresh coat of paint to the weather-beaten boards. He finishes, pleased with the result. He begins putting his supplies away. Behind him, a small dog, a stray, trots up the road. Julian doesn’t notice. The dog looks at the jetty for a second, then walks right into it, into the fresh paint. Julian sees.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Hey! He tries to grab the dog but it runs down the jetty. Julian has left the door to the house open and the dog runs inside. Julian is about to follow when he stops suddenly. ON THE FLOOR going into the house is a trail of PAW PRINTS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julian digging determinedly through his garbage. Near the bottom, he finally finds what he’s looking for: Lucy’s note. He stares at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy heading out for lunch, her coat on. (We note the nurse’s station is decorated with paper hearts, etc.) As she exits the hospital, she realizes it is SURPRISINGLY WARM. She smiles, opens her coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy eats her lunch in the large park, the Lake on one side, the city skyline on the other. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The park is crowded on this gorgeous day. Heavy traffic on Lake Shore Drive beyond. Lucy squints into the sunlight gleaming off the Lake. Sounds nearby -- a BELL TOLLING noon. Children laughing, yelling. A pair of OLD MEN on the next bench over.

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN
dialogues.text: What’s with the damn weather? 60 degrees on Valentine’s Day?

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN
dialogues.text: It’s global warming. Buckingham Fountain is not far off. It sends up a huge plume of water. Lucy gets up and starts towards it. She runs a hand through her hair, enjoying the feel of the sun on her face, some of the tension leaving her. Suddenly, a horrible SOUND -- a high-pitched grinding SQUEAL. Lucy looks around. A HUNDRED YARDS AWAY -- on the opposite side of the fountain from Lucy -- a double-length city bus is trying to stop. It’s going quite fast even though from the sound of things, the driver is absolutely crushing the brake. Lucy just registers all of this -- the sound, the bus -- before she notices the MAN standing directly in the bus’s path. There is nothing to be done; it is inevitable and almost immediate -- the man being struck by the bus, and his small, distant figure arching into the air ten or fifteen feet before crashing onto the pavement. The faint sound of the impact reaches Lucy a half-second later, because of the distance. Lucy automatically pulls out her cell phone and dials. She speaks calmly.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: We need an ambulance in Grant Park, near Buckingham Fountain. A bus has struck a pedestrian: Get an EMS crew here now. She begins running.  15. Traffic is snarled around the halted bus. PEOPLE gathering. Lucy runs up, starts pushing through the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: I’m a doctor. Let me through. She reaches the man, who is lying twisted, his face bloody, obscured. She can’t move him because of risk of neck injury; there’s not very much she can do except for feel for a pulse, listen for breath. An ambulance pulls up. Two EMTs jump out.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Get a back board! One does. They strap him into it, Lucy working to get a pulse. The other EMT kneels to assist Lucy. They work intensely for a moment. Then he shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: EMT
dialogues.text: He’s done. Lucy keeps working as if she hasn’t heard. The EMT puts a hand on her shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: EMT
dialogues.text: Doctor. Beat. Lucy finally stops. She gets up. The EMTs pull a gurney out of the ambulance and prepare to remove the body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy pours herself a cup of coffee. Her hands are shaking. She takes a deep breath, willing them to stop. They do. Anna Klyczynski has been watching her.

dialogues.speaker: KLYCZYNSKI
dialogues.text: I heard about Buckingham Fountain. EMTs said you fought hard for the guy.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Yeah, I really knocked myself out. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Beat.

dialogues.speaker: KLYCZYNSKI
dialogues.text: I had a case once. Routine heart surgery. They invented the word ‘routine’ for this kind of surgery. He died on the table. His body just chose that time to go. It was nobody’s fault, and there was nothing I could have done differently (beat) I couldn’t sleep for weeks.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Thanks. I’m fine. She turns to go.

dialogues.speaker: KLYCZYNSKI
dialogues.text: Lucy? Lucy stops.

dialogues.speaker: KLYCZYNSKI
dialogues.text: You have anyone in the city? Any friends? Family? Lucy shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: KLYCZYNSKI
dialogues.text: Do me a favor. On your day off, get as far away from here as you can. Okay? Go someplace where you feel... most like yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julian, on his way to work, slips a note into the mailbox and raises the flag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy driving north out of the city. The day is clear and bright, sun gleaming on the water.  17.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy buys lunch in the same grocery we saw before. Same couple running the store. The Wife is behind the counter. She bends up. She recognizes Lucy. STOREOWNER’S WIFE Hey. We haven’t seen you for a while. How’s Chicago?

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Okay. STOREOWNER’S WIFE What are you doing back here?

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Just needed to get out of the city. When the weather’s like this, you’ve got to. STOREOWNER’S WIFE I know it -- What is it, sweetie? to pick up a TODDLER, about 2, who has just run

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Hi there. STOREOWNER’S WIFE Say hi.

dialogues.speaker: TODDLER
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julian, working, eating a sandwich. The day hasn’t gotten much warmer and the wind is blowing strongly. Mona stops by, heading to the office with her lunch.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Trailer’s nice and warm.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Love to. Can’t.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: (looks at the sky) God, it’s really miserable. Don’t catch a cold or anything on me, all right?  18.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: (grins) I never get sick. She follows him as he works.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: You find a place to stay yet?

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Yeah. Just outside of town, up the shore a little bit.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Up the shore...? I don’t... Wait, not that house with the thing, the walkway thing, and the stilts...

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: That’s not on the Lake, it’s in the Lake. That place has been standing empty for years. What made you take that?

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Well, I --

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Oh, goddamn it. Her high heels are sinking into the muddy ground. She puts a hand on Julian’s shoulder as she pulls her feet free. One shoe stays stuck. Julian gets it out for her.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Get yourself some boots. Mona nods, smiles at him, watches as he wipes off her shoe for her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy throws a stick, playing fetch with her dog on the beach, wind whipping her hair. Sun low on the horizon. Soon it will be time to go back, but she’s in no hurry to.  19.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: They come over a dune and the DOG BARKS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The LAKE HOUSE, not far off. The dog runs towards it.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: She follows, keeping up. They approach the house. The dog trots over to the jetty but Lucy picks him up before he can run across. She looks at the house for a moment. It is empty, silent. Lucy turns to walk away. Then she notices the mailbox with its raised flag. Acting on an impulse, she opens it. INSIDE is a single envelope. She pulls it out. To her surprise, it is addressed to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy sits parked outside the House, reading the letter.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: (reads aloud) ‘I got your note. Is it supposed to be some kind of joke? If it is, I don’t get it. Lucy looks perplexed.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: ‘I’m not the “previous tenant.” There was no previous tenant. I thought maybe you had the wrong place. But how did you know about the paw prints?’ Lucy is baffled. She thinks for a moment, then digs in her bag for a pen and paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julian pulls up in his pickup, after work. The flag on the mailbox is up. He opens the box. Lucy’s new letter is inside. He looks at it as he walks along the jetty. It has a return address: 1620 RACINE.  20.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: As Julian lets himself in, something leaps onto him.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Agh! What -- It’s the stray dog, which Julian has evidently kept. It licks Julian’s face. (We notice, if we haven’t before, that this dog looks a great deal like Lucy’s dog.)

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Oh yeah. You. He puts the dog down. He opens Lucy’s letter and begins to read.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An architecture class. A half-dozen GRADUATE STUDENTS (black clothes, hipster/pretentious eyewear, etc.) sit around a seminar table. One student, HENRY FERRIS, 29, presents a project. A severe-looking professor, BURNHAM, 60, watches.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: My project is informed and inspired by a metaphor of the loop, or fugue -- interlocking, repeating patterns in time and/or space that generate meaning and structural complexity via their contrapuntal interweaving and mutual interdependence, as much as by paradox and apparent contradiction. Around the table -- generally approving looks. Henry pulls out a rolled-up poster.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Specifically, as exemplified in the work of M.C. Escher, in his ‘Relativity.’ He shows the Escher engraving of a dizzying building, staircases and ramps leading around in endless, impossible loops. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: ..- which I have re-rendered and reconceived here as a real-world contemporary structure incorporating offices, public space, a food court, and a 12- screen multiplex. Beat. Burnham squints at Henry’s proposal.

dialogues.speaker: BURNHAM
dialogues.text: So if I understand this correctly, you’re proposing to build this Escher engraving.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: With some significant modifications, but essentially, yes. Everyone takes this in.

dialogues.speaker: BURNHAM
dialogues.text: Interesting. I have only two comments, Mr. Ferris. Henry looks eager.

dialogues.speaker: BURNHAM
dialogues.text: One, this makes no fucking sense at all. Two, the assignment was to design a single-family home. Don’t waste the class’s time, Henry. (turns to the class) All right, who’s got something we can build here on Earth?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry comes out of class, chagrined, walking with VANESSA (another student, mousy/arty look).

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: God, I mean what is the point of putting yourself out there in the visionary vanguard if you’re just going to get shot down?

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: I thought your concept was really bold.  22.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: It’s like, if you don’t take risks as an architect, if you don’t at least try to push the envelope, you wind up, I don’t know, remodeling kitchens for yuppies...

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: Exactly. I --

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (surprised) Hey! As he exits the building Henry sees JULIAN outside, waiting on the plaza in front of the school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julian grins as Henry comes over.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: He’s back!

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Believe it or not.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: What are you doing here? You’re supposed to be this busy, important man.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Never too busy to look up an old friend and buy him a drink.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I am truly touched.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: And I had to run an errand in town. Henry laughs. They hug.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: It’s good to see you. JULIAN’S POV - OVER HENRY’S SHOULDER He sees Professor Burnham come out of the building. Their eyes meet. Burnham freezes. Then walks on, as if he hadn’t noticed him.  23.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Julian watches him go.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Let’s get out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crowded Chicago bar. Julian and Henry sit at a table with burgers and beers.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: So. How’s life in condo world?

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Well, it’s a challenge managing a project so big, sometimes it’s frustrating, but basically I --

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Just tell me how much money you’re making.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Forget it.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Come on, a hint.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: I bought a house.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: That much?

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: On the Lake.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: That much? Shit.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Don’t worry. I’m mortgaged up to my eyeballs.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Still. Lake House. God. I guess that makes selling out your dreams and betraying your talent totally worth it.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Yep.  24.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He clinks his glass against Henry’s and drinks. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: You never think about coming back to school?

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Never.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: You sure? You’re content just to be this upwardly-mobile cliche.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Yeah. (he drinks) I even got a dog.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (rolls his eyes) Shit. INT. JULIAN’S TRUCK - NIGHT Julian drives around Chicago’s North Side.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Hank.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Burnham ever ask where I went?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: No. Beat. Julian is silent for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: You should have seen him rake me over the coals today. He hates me.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: He doesn’t hate you. (beat) He hates your work... They laugh. Beat. Julian turns a corner.  25.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julian walks down the street, looking for an address.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: 1620 Racine.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: I’m not sure.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Who lives there?

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: So why are we going?

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Okay. Julian crosses the street, notes an address on a building.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Here’s sixteen hundred.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: So sixteen hundred twenty should be... Henry walks to the next lot down. He is standing in front of a PIT. Just a recently-dug foundation, no building. They stare at it.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: So should we buzz up, or what? Julian takes a piece of paper out of his pocket. Lucy’s last letter. The return address is correct: 1620 Racine.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Perhaps there has been some sort of mistake. Julian looks at the letter itself. It is dated MARCH 20, 2004.  26.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy comes in, studying a new letter from Julian. We can read the words “Mistake... tried to deliver this in person... wrong address... also the date (?!)” She picks up the pad and begins to write, exasperated.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I got your last letter. I’m not quite sure I’m writing back but I guess I want to get to the bottom of this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julian in his kitchen, reading the letter.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: By the way, for some reason the mail isn’t getting forwarded to me. I’ve had to drive up there to get it. Anyway, no, I did not get the address wrong. I know where I live. Okay, it’s ugly, but it’s not quite an open pit. Julian smiles.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: And I know the date, too. It’s 2004. He laughs. This is some sort of insane joke.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Just curious: what year do you think it is? Behind Julian -- the calendar on his wall is open to the MARCH, 2002 page. INT. LUCY’S APARTMENT - NIGHT Lucy studies a letter from Julian. CLOSE ON the date, underlined: “2002.” And the words -- AND STOP BULLSHITTING ME, PLEASE. She snorts, incredulous. The dog looks at her. She pets it, thinking. Then she gets up. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She goes to a closet and takes down a shoebox. It’s full of photographs. She dumps them out and begins sorting through them. She pauses to look at one. A younger Lucy with a BOYFRIEND -- MORGAN, 30, slightly bland good looks. They’re in each other’s arms, laughing, in love. She looks at it for a second, then puts it away and keeps searching. She finally finds the photo she’s looking for. It shows Lucy and some friends, outside at night, wearing T- shirts and jeans, with snow falling around them. She flips it over. On the back is an auto-printed date: APRIL 3, 2002.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WIND BLOWING fiercely as Julian arrives home to find the flag on the mailbox up. A new letter from Lucy inside. He retrieves it and walks across the jetty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THROUGH the window we can see thick clouds collecting over the lake as Julian reads the letter.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Since you don’t believe me, a little warning. There was a bad flu going around in the Spring of 2002. I remember because there was a freak late snow, and after that everybody got sick. Julian rolls his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: So, my mystery correspondent, if you really are where -- or when -- you say you are... I hope you’re getting plenty of rest and drinking lots of fluids. This is too much for Julian.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Snow, right.  28.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He crumples the letter and goes to throw it away. He’s about to drop it in the trash when he suddenly SNEEZES. It takes a second for this to register, and by the time it does, he sneezes again. He whirls around. OUTSIDE THE WINDOW -- beautiful SNOW is swirling into the Lake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The mailbox is covered with a thick dusting of snow. Julian very tentatively opens it. He quickly slips ina letter and closes the box, almost as if he’s afraid it will bite him. He pulls the red flag up. EXT. MAILBOX - DAY (LUCY’S CONTINUITY) The mailbox is dry; it’s a warm day two years later. Lucy opens the box and takes out Julian’s letter. She puts the flag down. She opens the letter. It has a single line.

dialogues.speaker: CAN THIS BE HAPPENING
dialogues.text: Lucy, hands shaking, takes out a pen. EXT. MAILBOX (JULIAN’S CONTINUITY) Julian stares at the snow-covered box. The flag is now down. He is starting to look a little freaked out. Also, he has the flu. He suddenly doubles over and sneezes violently. When he looks back at the mailbox, the flag is up. He nearly jumps back in alarm. He very hesitantly opens the mailbox and takes out... his note. The same one he just put in. He’s slightly disappointed, but also reassured. He relaxes a bit. He flips the note open and his jaw drops. Underneath his line “CAN THIS BE HAPPENING?” is Lucy’s handwriting, a single word: YES.  29. INT. LUCY’S APARTMENT - NIGHT Lucy comes home, a little dazed. Her dog jumps up on her. She carries it into her bedroom and sits down on her bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julian on his bed, nursing his flu, staring at the note, still struggling to believe this. His dog jumps up and settles into his lap. INT. LUCY’S APARTMENT - NIGHT Lucy on her bed, writing.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: (out loud) I don’t know where to start.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julian reads Lucy’s letter.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I don’t even know the right questions to ask. Is there anything you can tell me that might shed some light on this? Julian thinks. He looks at the paw prints tracking into the house. INT. LUCY’S APARTMENT - NIGHT Lucy reads. CLOSE ON a line from Julian’s letter: I THINK WE HAVE THE SAME DOG.

dialogues.speaker: SAME SCENE
dialogues.text: Lucy at her desk. She writes back.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Does yours jump on you when you come home and scare the shit out of you?  30.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julian reads this.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Yes. He turns the page.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: (reads aloud) ‘And does he sleep like a person?’ He looks over at his bed. His dog lies asleep on his back, mouth open. He does look like a person. Julian starts to laugh. He looks back at the letter.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I call him Jack. He looks at the dog.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: So you’re Jack. (correcting himself, in amazement) You... will be Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy exiting a train in the morning rush hour.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Maybe we should introduce ourselves properly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy arrives at the hospital, signs in, gets a stack of charts and files.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I’m a doctor -- a first year resident in internal medicine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julian directing activity and conferring with Mona and Mulhern at the worksite. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: I build houses. I mean, I help run a company that builds houses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy reads.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Okay. I’m still trying to get this straight. If in two years you’ll be living in an apartment building at 1620 Racine... which doesn’t exist yet... where are you, uh, ‘now’? Lucy shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: I’m in medical school, Madison, Wisconsin. (she looks around, writes) I mean, in ‘my’ now I’m ina hospital cafeteria in Chicago, Illinois, but for you... Okay, this is weird. This is weird.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julian, on a break, scribbles on a pad.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: What’s it like in 2004?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy rides him from work. Train packed with weary commuters.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: It’s amazing. Everyone drives these flying cars. We all dress in shiny metal jumpsuits. Oh, and the Cubs won the series last year.

dialogues.speaker: HOUSE
dialogues.text: Julian reads, smiling.  32.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Actually, nothing’s changed much. No. Cell phones are a little smaller... INT. LUCY’S APARTMENT - NIGHT Lucy watching Back to the Future on TV. Doc Brown is yelling at Marty McFly.

dialogues.speaker: DOC BROWN, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: (on TV) Great Scott, Marty, do you realize what you’ve done? You’ve upset the entire space-time continuum!

dialogues.speaker: SAME SCENE
dialogues.text: Lucy writes.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Okay. One thing worries me. What if, in sending these letters, in communicating like this, we accidentally tamper with the course of time itself, altering human history forever in the process?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julian walks across the jetty.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Yeah, good point. lLet’s not do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lets himself into the house. Jack jumps up onto him.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Aggh! (firm) No. He sets Jack back on the floor, immediately goes back outside and comes in again. Jack jumps up. Julian puts him on the floor firmly and holds him there.  33.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: No. Julian repeats this several times. Finally he enters and Jack stays down. Julian gives him a treat.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Good boy! INT. LUCY’S APARTMENT - CORRIDOR Lucy reads the latest letter as she gets out of her elevator.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Sorry. I did have to change one thing. Lucy opens the door. Jack is sitting placidly, looking up at her.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: You’re welcome.

dialogues.speaker: ON LUCY
dialogues.text: beginning to laugh -- the first time we’ve seen her enjoy any sort of release, and we --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s a bright, warm day. Lucy at the mailbox. She pulls the flag upright.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Thanks for the favor. Here’s one back at you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Overcast, cold, wind. Julian opens the mailbox and pulls something out. He keeps pulling -- it’s a long, bright scarf. He tries it on, surprised.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Put this on and don’t take it off for the rest of the month. It’s onna stay cold till the middle of pril.  34.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julian fills a cement mixer. He’s wearing jeans, work boots, work gloves -- and the scarf. Mulhern looks askance at him.

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: EXT. LUCY’S APARTMENT BUILDING/EXT. LAKE MICHIGAN SPLIT SCREEN. Julian and Lucy both writing. Lucy on the roof of her building, where she can see the Lake behind the city buildings; Julian on the shore with Jack in his pickup. It’s warmer in both continuities: Spring is here,

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: If we’re going to keep doing this, we’ve got to know more about each other. Send me lists.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julian in the kitchen. He has a cocktail recipe book and has set out gin and lime juice and a cocktail shaker. He mixes a drink as Jack watches.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Okay. Let’s see. I like dogs, as you know. Gimlets -- that’s gin and lime juice, delicious on a warm night. I like the Stones’ Exile on Main Street. Jane Austen. I like... I love... my work. (joking) Turnoffs: cruelty, infectious diseases, and guys with mustaches. Julian tastes the gimlet and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy, sipping a milkshake, goes up the steps of the museum.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: For me: Milkshakes, black and white. Money Jungle by Duke Ellington. Cary Grant and Ingrid Bergman in Notorious... The Art Institute of Chicago on a quiet afternoon.  35.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy stands in front of a canvas of boats on the water.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: I forgot one. I like the Lake House.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A MATCHING SHOT, of Julian looking at sailboats on the actual Lake.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: How’d you wind up living here, anyway? INT. LUCY’S APARTMENT - NIGHT Lucy sprawls on her bed, writing.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I rented it after med school. It was the strangest place I’d ever seen. I couldn’t imagine anyone building it. Or... I couldn’t imagine building it and then not living here. I loved the way it sort of... hovered over the water. I loved that jetty. I don’t know why.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sunset. Darkness falling over the water. Julian sits on the jetty, writing.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: You have to leave land to get to the front door. It’s like getting on a ship. Every time you come home you’re embarking on a voyage. (he winces) Sorry. Pretentious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy writing.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Don’t apologize. You can be pretentious. You can be anything you like.  36.

dialogues.speaker: DOWN THE HALL
dialogues.text: A small party is in progress for Costello’s birthday. Cake and coffee, a dozen doctors talking, laughing. After the toast, FIND Anna Klyczynski looking around. She goes out into the corridor. She sees Lucy, sitting alone at the end of the hallway, deeply engrossed in her letter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julian writing intently at his desk. Mona is watching him from across the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few weeks have passed. WIND blowing fiercely on a late spring Chicago day. Lucy waiting for the train on a crowded platform. Her CELL PHONE rings.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Hello? (her explanation changes) Oh. Hi.

dialogues.speaker: SAME SCENE
dialogues.text: Lucy still on the phone. She sounds upset.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: (on phone) Look, it’s not easy for me, either. You know that... no, I’m not mad that you called. I just... I’m sorry, I’ve got to get to work and I -- A train is approaching the station.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: I don’t think that’s a good idea. No. Morgan, I’m saying please don’t come down. Because we need more time... Especially if we’re going to stay friends. I just don’t think we should... The train is about to leave.  37.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: (on phone) Look, I gotta go -- She runs for it but the doors close in her face and she groans in frustration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy near the end of her shift, about to check out. Madhvi Patel approaches her.

dialogues.speaker: MADHVI
dialogues.text: Lucy. I need a favor. I've got to have the night off. Take my shift?

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Tonight?

dialogues.speaker: MADHVI
dialogues.text: (shyly) Please? I've got a date. He just asked me, and I really want to. I'll cover for you next time. Lucy's exhausted, but she nods. She watches as Madhvi dashes off excitedly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy after her double shift struggles down the street with armfuls of groceries, Jack tugging at a leash. Car HORNS BLARING. A BIKE MESSENGER nearly runs her down. She looks strung-out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julian opens the mailbox to find it empty. He's surprised at how disappointed he feels.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Hey, pen pal. You haven't written for awhile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy soaks in a tub, looking drained, reading this letter.  38.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: It's been a... rough week. I worked 30 hours straight. I haven't been able to get away. I can't remember the last time I looked at the sky, or saw a damn tree. (beat) It's not so bad when I'm busy. It's when I have a minute to breathe, to look around, that it seems really hard. I wonder what the hell I'm doing here, alone, in this gray city. And I miss the way the world looked from the window of the Lake House.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julian reads this letter. Beat. He looks out the window. OUTSIDE are dozens of INFANT TREES waiting to be planted on the construction site.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy, coming home from work on the train. Out the window she can see it's beginning to rain. She sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julian drives toward Chicago on a cloudless evening. In the back of his pickup truck is one of the TREES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy trudges down the rainy street toward her building. A CLAP of THUNDER and the rain begins falling really hard, sheets. She yelps and starts running for her door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julian digs a HOLE outside the construction site that will become Lucy's apartment building. He finishes and starts to set the tiny, fragile tree in place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy is completely soaked as she runs the last few yards to her front door. She struggles for her keys, dropping them, growing more and more frustrated as the rain absolutely pounds down on her, when suddenly -- IT STOPS. She is baffled, as THUNDER and lightning continue to crack across the sky, and indeed the rain is still falling all around her, but not ON her. She looks up. Above her are the branches of a YOUNG TREE, leaves grown thick and high enough to form a canopy swaying in the rain just above Lucy. It wasn't there a second ago but now it's sheltering her, and she gapes at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julian smiles as he tosses the shovel in the back of his truck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON Lucy, moved, her face breaking into a wide smile.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: (quietly) Thank you. Drops of rain fall through the green branches as Lucy spins slowly beneath the tree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry is standing on the jetty facing the Lake House. He has just arrived.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: You... bastard... Julian gestures for Henry to follow him inside. Henry is too flabbergasted by the house.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: This is where you’ve been hiding out? This is yours?

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Yeah. Henry follows Julian inside, appraising the place.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: When was it built?

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Seventies. You want a beer?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Yeah. Henry looks around.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: It’s like Le Corbusier meets Frank Lloyd Wright meets... me in five years. It’s perfect.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Actually, it’s not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stand on a narrow ledge that runs along the back of the house. There’s a fifteen-foot drop down to the water.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: You can’t swim. There should be a stairway down to the water. Maybe a porch. Something.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (shakes his head) It would ruin the line. Total aesthetic catastrophe.  41.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They sit in the darkness, listening to the WATER LAPPING, drinking beer. ROLLING STONES ON the STEREO inside.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Exile. Cool.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Yeah. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Julian. I didn't just come up here to escape my pathetic existence in the city.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: You didn't?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: No. There's an agenda. (beat) If you dropped this bourgeois 'thing' and came back we could still graduate together in a year. Start the Firm.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: "Visionary Vanguard Associates.’

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Visionary Vanguard. I can't do it alone.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: (shakes his head) Sorry, Hank. Beat. Henry treads carefully.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I'm sure if you talked to him...

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Forget it.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Jules.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: He doesn't want me back. I don't want to be back. Everybody's happier now.  42.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: What about your work? Your work was great. Even he admitted that. Look, I know it's hard, but if you suck it up and put all the personal shit aside for a few months, you'll have your degree, and --

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: I said forget it. His tone is sharp. Henry is quiet.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Sorry. I just... like it up here.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Are you involved with somebody?

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: (beat)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Why did you hesitate?

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: I didn't.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Yes you did.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: I -- I'm not involved with anybody, okay?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Okay. (beat) All I'm saying is, maybe you should think about the future. Julian starts to laugh. He can't stop. Henry looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: What? (as Julian keeps laughing) What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy has an old 2002 filofax calendar open on her desk. She turns the pages until she sees an entry, circled: "5:46 TO MADISON." She picks up a pen, writes.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Let's try something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julian driving. He turns into the parking lot of a local train station, parks and gets out. Rain is falling. BEYOND, a train is just pulling into the station.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Around 'your' time two years ago I lost something. At a train station. I was on my way back to school and I left it on the platform. See if you can find it for me. I won't tell you what it is. Then put it in the mailbox. This is your mission if you choose to accept it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julian walks through the station. A few PEOPLE about. He looks for single women. He doesn't see any -- just a couple of FAMILIES, an ELDERLY COUPLE, some BUSINESSMEN.

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCEMENT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Final call for the 5:46 to Madison, making the following stops... Julian keeps searching. No luck. Suddenly, THROUGH the window that looks out onto the train platform, he sees a YOUNG WOMAN stand up and prepare to board the train. It's Lucy -- here two years younger, a med student. Julian doesn't know for sure that it's her, but she could be the person he's looking for, and she's startlingly pretty besides. He hurries through the door out onto the train platform.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is about to go over to her when he stops. She has her arms around a MAN whose BACK is TO us. They're embracing under an umbrella, saying goodbye. Neither has noticed that Lucy has left a book on the bench where they were sitting. Julian sees it, but it would be awkward to go over and interrupt the kiss. He hesitates. The TRAIN CONDUCTOR announces final boarding. Lucy reluctantly breaks off from the man and gets on the train. The man Lucy was kissing doesn't move. He stands under his umbrella, watching as the train pulls out, and doesn't leave until it is completely out of sight. He never notices the book. Julian watches him go. Once he's gone, Julian goes over to the bench. He looks at the book Lucy left. It is a well-worn copy of PERSUASION by Jane Austen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy driving along the lake, eager to get to the mailbox. She passes a LAKESIDE CONDO DEVELOPMENT. It's new, upscale, sprawling. Lucy mutters to herself.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Tacky. She drives on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy arrives at the Lake House and drives up to the mailbox, eager. She opens it. There's no book inside. Just a note. She opens it.

dialogues.speaker: ON LUCY
dialogues.text: She's a little disappointed.  45.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy changes clothes after work. In the b.g., Patel and Costello are also heading out.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Going to the fireworks, I guess. I go every year. Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julian drives toward the Loop, buildings glimmering in the twilight.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: What do you say we both go? EXT. HOSPITAL - NIGHT (LUCY’S CONTINUITY) Lucy walks out onto crowded downtown streets.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: You're not asking me out, are you?

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: No, no. I just thought it might be good to do the same thing, that's all.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: The same thing, two years apart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julian has parked his truck and joined the crowds moving down the streets.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Better than staying home. They arrive at the SAME CORNER from different directions.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Okay. Let's go to the fireworks. SPLIT SCREEN -- they both turn the corner, in both continuities -- and suddenly the RIVER is before them, thronged up and down with crowds of PEOPLE gathering in the warm summer night.  46.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julian stops at an Italian sausage stand run by a VENDOR in his 50s and an OLD MAN, the Vendor's father, who must be at least 80. The Vendor is about to hand Julian a sausage but his father stops him, piles some more onions and peppers on it for Julian.

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN
dialogues.text: Give the man his money's worth. (to Julian) I'm still teaching him the business.

dialogues.speaker: VENDOR
dialogues.text: (laughing) All right, Pop. Julian continues down to the river.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy stops at the sausage stand. The Vendor is two years older, a bit sadder-looking. He tends the stand alone.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: One, please. He nods, piles it high with onions and peppers.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Did you go to the station? I never got my book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julian walks through the crowds. He watches a HAPPY COUPLE go by.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Let me keep it for a while. I want to read it. (beat) There's something I've been meaning to ask you. Who was the guy at the train station?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy watches a DIFFERENT HAPPY COUPLE pass (and is surprised to see that it's Patel and Costello, holding hands away from the hospital, furtive lovers).  47.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julian stares up at the sky, in the middle of an expectant crowd, waiting for the fireworks.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Your fiance? Why didn't you tell me?

dialogues.speaker: LUCY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: You don't tell me about your love life.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Because I don't have one. Unfortunately. God, I can't believe you didn't say you're married.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy in her crowd by the river.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: (gentler) I'm not married. We broke up when I moved to Chicago. CHEERS as the show begins and the first FIREWORKS EXPLODE. She looks up at the sky.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I'm alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julian alone in the crowd as his fireworks show begins.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN, (V .0.)
dialogues.text: Okay. Me too. FIREWORKS EXPLODE AND ECHO in both continuities. Julian and Lucy watch, the lights playing on their upturned faces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy comes home. It's a hot night and her apartment is stifling. She gets ready for bed, stripping down to panties and tank top, and stands in front of a fan.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: So. How were your fireworks?  48.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julian strips down to boxers. He opens a window, trying to catch a breeze on his equally hot night.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Not as good as yours, I'll bet. They get better every year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SPLIT SCREEN -- the two of them, lying in different halves of their beds.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Yeah... They both lie there, hot and uncomfortable, tossing in frustration, separated by time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then Julian jumps up. He goes to his desk and pulls out a piece of paper. He writes: AT THE TRAIN STATION, I... He crosses this out and starts over. WHEN I SAW YOU... I WASN'T EXPECTING... He crosses this out too. Then takes a breath, and before he can stop himself, writes: YOU DIDN'T TELL ME YOU WERE SO BEAUTIFUL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy reads these words. She can’t suppress a startled little gasp. She looks around, embarrassed. No one has heard her. She writes:

dialogues.speaker: LUCY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: No fair. You saw me but I still don’t know what you look like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julian looks in the mirror, examines his hairline. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: You're right. I wouldn't mind knowing what I'm like in two years. Why don't you get together with 'me' in the future and let me know what you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy considers this.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Yeah. She takes a breath, suddenly excited and nervous. Her life could be about to change. She writes:

dialogues.speaker: OKAY... WHY NOT GIVE ME A CALL ON JULY 10, 2004, AT ABOUT
dialogues.text: She checks her watch. It's 9:04. She writes. 9:05.

dialogues.speaker: THE TIP OF HER PEN
dialogues.text: as it finishes the last curve of the "5" -- The PHONE RINGS. She nearly falls out of her chair. Lucy steadies herself. She gets up and crosses to the phone. She hesitates, then snatches up the receiver, heart racing.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: (whispers) Hello?

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: (on phone) Lucy?

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: (on phone) It's Morgan.  50.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: It takes a moment for this to sink in.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Morgan?

dialogues.speaker: MORGAN, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: (on phone) Yeah. I’m in Chicago. I came down for a meeting but it was cancelled, so I thought I'd give you a call. What the hell. See if you were free.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy walks with MORGAN -- the man from the train station, now two years older than when we last saw him, good- looking, nicely dressed. They walk in awkward silence.

dialogues.speaker: MORGAN
dialogues.text: Thanks for coming out.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: MORGAN
dialogues.text: Been too long. She doesn't answer. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: MORGAN
dialogues.text: How's Jack?

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: He's good.

dialogues.speaker: MORGAN
dialogues.text: Adjusting to city life?

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Yeah, he's doing great.

dialogues.speaker: MORGAN
dialogues.text: Good. I miss him. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: MORGAN
dialogues.text: Have you eaten, by any chance?  51.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: No, but --

dialogues.speaker: MORGAN
dialogues.text: Neither have I. I just realized I'm starving. We could grab a quick dinner. Lucy nods, reluctantly. They are passing a small, elegant restaurant -- "IL MARE."

dialogues.speaker: MORGAN
dialogues.text: How about this? Looks all right.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Oh, no, Morgan, this place is much too... But Morgan is already heading inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place is small and stylish and serene. Also absolutely packed. Morgan goes up to the HOSTESS.

dialogues.speaker: MORGAN
dialogues.text: Two for dinner.

dialogues.speaker: HOSTESS
dialogues.text: (taken aback) Tonight?

dialogues.speaker: MORGAN
dialogues.text: Yes, please.

dialogues.speaker: HOSTESS
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, sir. We're completely booked for tonight. She pages ahead through the reservation book.

dialogues.speaker: HOSTESS
dialogues.text: But three... no, I'm sorry, four months from now we have a dinner opening if you'd like to reserve. Five-thirty or eleven-thirty? ON Morgan, disappointed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bright, garish pizza place. Morgan and Lucy eat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks He shakes 52.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Don't feel bad. It's the best restaurant in the city. No one gets a table.

dialogues.speaker: MORGAN
dialogues.text: It's not that. (beat) I didn't do this right. at him.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: You didn't have a meeting, did you? his head. She waits for him to continue.

dialogues.speaker: MORGAN
dialogues.text: I thought you'd see me if it seemed like no big deal, a surprise, a quick coffee... But coffee could turn into dinner. And dinner could turn into... She shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: MORGAN
dialogues.text: Anything.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: So this was an ambush.

dialogues.speaker: MORGAN
dialogues.text: I guess so.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Another one.

dialogues.speaker: MORGAN
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Morgan. You were always leaping ten steps ahead. A week after we met you had our whole lives mapped out. When I was still at school, you were picking out real estate. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LUCY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'd come visit for the weekend and you'd have all your high school friends, the whole town at the house to meet me.

dialogues.speaker: MORGAN
dialogues.text: At least I didn't make out with somebody else.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: MORGAN
dialogues.text: At the party...

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Oh my God. I didn't make out with him! I kissed him, once, and it was just some random guy and it was years ago... I can't believe you even remember that.

dialogues.speaker: MORGAN
dialogues.text: Okay. You’re right. I don’t want to fight. (beat) It’s just... part of me wonders... if I had moved to Chicago when you wanted to --

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: You didn't. (beat; gentler) Leaving was the toughest decision I've ever made. I hope you know that.

dialogues.speaker: MORGAN
dialogues.text: Yeah. (sighs) I'm sorry. I never should have called. I just... miss you. Lucy doesn't answer. He pokes at his food, miserable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julian is parked in his truck outside the ARCHITECTURE SCHOOL. After a moment he gets out.  54.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burnham, the architecture professor, at work at his desk. A SOUND at the door. He looks up. Julian is standing in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: BURNHAM
dialogues.text: (quiet) This is a surprise.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: I was in the neighborhood... He trails off, uncomfortable. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: How've you been?

dialogues.speaker: BURNHAM
dialogues.text: I'm well. Burnham doesn't say anything else. Julian steps into the room, tentative.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: How's Margaret?

dialogues.speaker: BURNHAM
dialogues.text: She's in London for the year, teaching. Otherwise the same.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: You ever gonna marry her?

dialogues.speaker: BURNHAM
dialogues.text: Did you come here to make small talk?

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: No. Julian puts an envelope on Burnham's desk. Burnham looks inside. A check.

dialogues.speaker: BURNHAM
dialogues.text: What is this?

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: It's what I owe you.

dialogues.speaker: BURNHAM
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon?

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: You paid my tuition for two years. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BURNHAM
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: So you wasted your money.

dialogues.speaker: BURNHAM
dialogues.text: I really don't think we owe each other anything.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: I'd feel better.

dialogues.speaker: BURNHAM
dialogues.text: (shrugs) If it makes you feel better. Burnham looks at the check briefly, pockets it. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: There's something else. I bought the house.

dialogues.speaker: BURNHAM
dialogues.text: I heard a rumor. Word travels in this business.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: BURNHAM
dialogues.text: Yes. They said some sleazy little developer building McMansions up and down the lake shore snapped it up. Julian stares at him for a moment. Then abruptly exits, slamming the door behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burnham takes out the check again. He looks at it, then slowly tears it in half and drops the two pieces into a wastepaper basket. Then he opens a desk drawer and pulls out a photograph.

dialogues.speaker: PHOTO
dialogues.text: It is a photo of the Lake House under construction. Burnham stands on the jetty with a lovely WOMAN and a small BOY, about seven. The boy points at the house, his arms around his father's neck. Burnham holds the little boy in his arms, smiling and happy and proud.  56.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Burnham looks at the photo a moment, starts to drop it in the wastebasket as well, then decides not to. He puts it back in the drawer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is now autumn on the North Shore. Trees fiery and gorgeous against the deep, vivid blue of the lake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julian steps out the front door of a COMPLETED CONDO -- the first one to be finished. He shakes hands with Mulhern, making a little ceremony of it. Applause from the crew gathered around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julian and Mona sit in Julian's truck looking at the site. Jack is in the backseat.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: One down.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Forty-four to go.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: We're not terrifyingly behind schedule. Just... alarmingly. She looks anxious.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: It's gonna be okay. We'll catch up. We could use a couple more guys who know how to handle a backhoe. And the waterline to number fourteen needs to be resealed...

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Shut up.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: What? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: I'm kind of pissed at you, you know.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: You are?

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: I thought you were supposed to be on top of things around here.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: I thought I was.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Well you never noticed these. She puts a foot up on the dashboard. She's wearing new, rather flashy red cowboy boots.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Don't you remember? You told me to get them.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Right. Right. (laughs) Wow. Not exactly what I had in mind, but...

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: You like them or not? He looks at them. He also can't help looking at her leg. She grins.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: I like them.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Good. ‘Cause I was thinking... if you're not busy tonight, we should --

dialogues.speaker: IN THE BACK SEAT
dialogues.text: JACK suddenly GROWLS and LEAPS out of the window. Julian surprised.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Hey! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Julian scrambles out. Jack is dashing off over a hill. Julian shouts but the dog doesn't stop. Julian takes off running after him. Mona gets out.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Julian?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julian chases Jack down a nearby residential street. The dog is speedy. Julian racing to keep up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack darts across someone's yard. Julian still chasing. AHEAD, a MAN in his driveway is unloading boxes from his car trunk. He sees what's happening and, quick on his feet, manages to scoop Jack up in his arms as the dog dashes past. Julian runs up, winded.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: No problem. The MAN is MORGAN -- here, two years younger than we saw him last. Julian has only seen him once before, under an umbrella in the train station, and doesn't recognize him.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: He's never run off like that.

dialogues.speaker: MORGAN, (MAN)
dialogues.text: Gotta keep an eye on them. What's his name?

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Jack.

dialogues.speaker: MORGAN
dialogues.text: (petting him) Hi, Jack. I should get one like you for my girlfriend. She loves dogs. Julian notes all of Morgan's boxes -- cases of beer and wine.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Let me give you a hand with that.  59.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mona, far behind and hobbled by the boots (which are hard to run in), stumbles down the street looking for Julian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julian helps Morgan carry in the boxes. Morgan is a genial, chatty guy. Julian listening politely.

dialogues.speaker: MORGAN
dialogues.text: I do some real estate law, contracts, wills, whatever people need around here. Big stuff, small stuff.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: MORGAN
dialogues.text: (smiles) Okay, mostly small stuff. How about you? You lived here long?

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Just a few months. I've got a place on the Lake.

dialogues.speaker: MORGAN
dialogues.text: Nice. They're done. Mona comes limping up, winded.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Oh, thank God. You found him.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Yeah. Morgan nods "hi" to Mona.

dialogues.speaker: MORGAN
dialogues.text: Hey, just so you don't think I'm planning to drink all this by myself -- I'm having a bunch of friends over tonight. Locals. You two are welcome to come. Julian and Mona exchange a glance.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Thanks. We've got plans. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MORGAN
dialogues.text: No problem. Good to meet you anyway. See you later, Jack. Oh, hey, Julian -- (reaches into his pocket) Take my card? I might be looking to rent a place on the Lake myself. If you hear of anything, would you let me know?

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: MORGAN
dialogues.text: Thanks. I like this house, but my girlfriend doesn't. You know how it is.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Sure. Mona and Julian start off.

dialogues.speaker: MORGAN
dialogues.text: I promised her a Lake view if she moves here after med school. Julian stops.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: She's in medical school?

dialogues.speaker: MORGAN
dialogues.text: Yeah. In Madison. She comes down on the weekends, though. Julian stares. He finally realizes that Morgan 1s the man who was on the train platform with Lucy.

dialogues.speaker: MORGAN
dialogues.text: She's coming in later tonight, actually. That's why I'm throwing the party. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: What time does it start? Mona stares at Julian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy comes out after work, tired. Starts to head for the El. Then changes her mind and stops. She reverses direction and walks down the street until she comes to a bar -- the Cove, the place the other doctors told her about. She goes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place is dead, mostly empty. She goes to the bar and sits down, glum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julian and Mona arrive at Morgan's house. Party in progress inside. Cars parked in the driveway, on the street. They start inside.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: This better be good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morgan among his FRIENDS and NEIGHBORS, talking, laughing.

dialogues.speaker: MORGAN
dialogues.text: You wouldn’t catch me dead in Chicago. I grew up here. You'd have to be nuts to live anywhere else. I -- He stops Julian and Mona as they come in.

dialogues.speaker: MORGAN
dialogues.text: Hey! Glad you could make it. Bar's in the kitchen... They move through the rooms. A pretty dull crowd. Mona gives him a "why are we here?" look. No sign of Lucy anywhere. They eventually sit on the couch next to DOUG and MARJORIE, a couple in their 30s. Doug sticks out his hand.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Doug Ryan. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Julian.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Mona.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: I teach Earth Sciences at the middle school. Marjorie coaches Speech and Debate. She's an expert in public speaking. Isn't that right, honey? 62. Marjorie nods but doesn't say anything. Uncomfortable beat.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: You know anything about Earth Sciences? Julian shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Anna Klyczynski appears and sits down at the bar next to Lucy. She orders a drink.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: According to most accepted social norms a person should not drink alone after ten P.M., unless they have a good excuse. What's yours?

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Don't have one.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I do. My youngest left for college this morning. Marie. (shakes her head ) There was this little girl splashing around in a wading pool in diapers in my back yard. And now she's packing her Volvo to drive to California. I have no goddamn idea where the time went. (smiles) She's going to be pre-med at Stanford. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: That's great.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: (proud) Yeah. (drinks) You want another one?

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Yeah. Anna orders. The drinks come. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Okay. I do have an excuse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julian and Mona are still on the couch with Doug and Marjorie, looking restless. Doug is using two paper plates to illustrate what he's saying.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: All of the Earth's continents rest on tectonic plates. Now these plates are continually moving and shifting...

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: (to Julian, out of the side of her mouth) Get the coats.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Excuse me for a sec, Doug. Julian gets up.

dialogues.speaker: ELSEWHERE
dialogues.text: Morgan is looking out the window.

dialogues.speaker: MORGAN
dialogues.text: Okay, everybody! This is it! Morgan turns out all the lights in the room. Everyone quiets. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: After a moment a figure carrying an overnight bag comes into the darkened room. Lucy.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Hello? Morgan flips on the lights. Everyone yells "Surprise,” "Happy Birthday," etc. Someone carries in a cake blazing with candles. Lucy looks stunned. Morgan kisses her. Julian watches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy and Anna at the bar.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Why didn't you mention it was your birthday? We would have had a cake for you or something.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: It's just time passing. I hate making a big deal out of it. Anna looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: You keep a lot to yourself. Lucy doesn't say anything.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
